awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Modernizing Classical Nonparametric and Multivariate Theory for Large-scale,  High-dimensional Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The constantly increasing dimensionality and complexity of modern data has motivated many new data analysis tools in various fields, and urgently call for rigorous theoretical investigation, such as robustness against different sources of model misspecification,uncertainty quantification in classification and prediction, and statistical performance guarantee of conventional methods under non-standard settings. Although most classical theory are not directly applicable to methods developed for complex data, partially due to highly specialized model assumptions and diversified algorithms, the profound statistical thinking carried in these long-established results can still provide deep theoretical insights. When combined with cutting-edge results in modern context such as random matrix theory, matrix concentration, and convex geometry, these classical theory will lead to novel principled methods for a general class of problems ranging from high dimensional regression and classification to network data analysis and subspace learning. All methods developed in the proposed research will be implemented as standard R packages freely available and will have high pedagogical value and will be used to develop new courses. The proposed research has applications in astronomy and medical screening data. The proposal also provides new inference tools for applied areas in genetics, psychiatry, brain sciences. Integrated educational activities include designing courses on new perspectives in nonparametric statistics and modern multivariate analysis.

The proposed work will further integrate classical nonparametric and multivariate analysis theory with modern elements in four major areas of statistical research, including assumption-free prediction bands in high dimensional regression; a generalized Neyman-Pearson framework for set-valued multi-class classification; statistical performance guarantee of some greedy algorithms in network community detection as well as goodness-of-fit tests for network model selection; and a unified singular value decomposition framework for structured subspace estimation formulated as a convex optimization problem.  These research activities will lead to modernized nonparametric and multivariate analysis courses, featuring new theoretical frameworks such as computationally constrained minimax analysis, additional topics such as functional data analysis, and cutting-edge examples in genetics, brain imaging, traffic, and astronomy.

por.por_cntn:
The PI has completed research work under the support of NSF grant ``CAREER: Modernizing Classical Nonparametric and Multivariate Theory for Large-scale, High-dimensional Data Analysis''.

 

The PI has successfully extended a new framework of distribution free inference, namely the conformal prediction, to more general scenarios including high-dimensional regression and multi-class classification, developing new methods for uncertainty quantification, variable selection, and model comparison under very weak model assumptions.  These methods are later found to be closely related to many classical topics such as cross-validation, conditional likelihood, leading to new insights and improved variants of these classical tools.  On other hand, recent developments on this topic have started making connection and improvements in modern areas such as causal inference and transfer learning.

 

On network data analysis, the PI developed two of the earliest provably consistent model selection procedures for network data with community structures.  These method combines classical statistical ideas such as goodness-of-fit and cross-validation with modern tools such as random matrix theory and spectral analysis to obtain efficient and mathematically sound inference for network data.  Another result is a consistent clustering method for multiple networks sharing a common hidden community structure under a relaxed set of conditions.  At the core of this method is a new tensor concentration bound extended from the matrix case. Both the model selection problem and multiple layer network data analysis have become very active research area with exciting developments.

 

On the study of high-dimensional low-rank matrix data, the PI has developed multiple new methods are developed for the analysis of RNA-sequencing data, including both tissue (bulk) RNA-seq data and single cell (sc) RNA-seq data.  One such method is a novel two-sample sparse covariance matrix test for detecting schizophrenia risk genes, which allows us to identify groups of genes with differential correlation patterns between the control and case groups.  Other methods include a unified inference framework for integrated analysis of bulk and sc RNA-seq data by combining ideas from topic modeling and hierarchical bayes inference, and a soft clustering method for single cell RNA-seq data that provides soft clustering with lineage embeddings of each cell to reflect the evolution stages. These methods provide new and powerful tools for extracting hidden information in massive genomics data. The findings are able to help improve or confirm our evolving understanding of the genetic causes of schizophrenia and other neurological disorders.  The soft clustering method provides a tool that produces a more refined picture of cell evolution in different developmental stages.

 

On the educational side, the PI also developed a one-semester course on modern multivariate analysis, which starts from more standard materials in multivariate analysis but also covers substantial amount of recent developments such as high-dimensional Gaussian comparison, sparse principal components analysis, spectral clustering, and high-dimensional robust inference, much of which is from the PI's own research.  This course has been offered once at Carnegie Mellon University.  The PI is also developing a course on distribution-free inference, with a focus on conformal prediction.  A short course on this topic has been given when the PI was visiting University of Cambridge, UK.  A set of preliminary lecture notes are available on the PI's website.
